Why are measuring apparatus are round and not cuboidal? I ask this because it's a measuring instrument and to calculate the inner volume of something round, you need pie and will end in a lot of decimals. Calculating the inner something that has flat faces is straightforward and will less likely end up with a lot of decimals. Theobromine may help prevent development off Myopia. During the years when children’s eye-balls grow into the final adult size and shape, Theobromine appears to hinder development of eye-ball elongation which is the direct optical reason for Myopia (lens no longer brings light into focus on the retina). Development of severe Myopia can be a reason for detached retinas later in life due to the elongation, and therefore the suggested treatment with Theobromine medication during youth may not only reduce levels of Myopia as an adult, but also hinder blindness due to detached retina. Trials of the treatment are being conducted with placebo experiments, on children, after development and testing on rabbits. Lab animals were fine, and a significant reduction of development of Myopia was detected in the groups of children who did receive the Theobromine. One day there could be ‘pills against near-sightedness’.

I find a good way to clean dry, insoluble "gunk" from glass is to mix salt with alcohol to form a type of liquid abrasive. Pour it into whatever it is you're trying to clean and shake and/or apply some other vigorous mechanical action . Then dilute with water and just rinse thoroughly. It may be tricky with certain pieces but I have had fairly decent results with this method in my experience.

Just a note on cocoa powder, Don't know if it effects theobromine extraction too much. Cocoa comes in two main types(and blends of them) natural and Dutch processed. Sadly marketing bozos often neglect to clarify on the packaging.
Natural is basically ground nibs with the fat pressed out, more tannic flavor and reddish/cinnamon in color.
Dutch is treated with an alkali which makes it much darker brown-black, richer and much less tannic in flavor, most chocolate bars use dutch to some degree.

Hi! I have a challenge for you.

Up here in the Northern Sweden, a weekend hike can turn into a survival situation if you get wet, get lost or get stuck. Often these situations don't have a happy ending and we have about 20-30 deaths per year in these forests. Most of the time, you never find them again.

I have a Primus Eta Solo stove that I love. The prominent feature is that it has metal fins sticking out from the bottom, like a heatsink, giving optimum heat transfer even during unfavourable conditions. This means that your small cylinder of isobutane will heat up as much food as a large cylinder of isobutane when using an old style boiling pan.

Now on my last hike I ended up in a bad situation, and hypothermia was about to set in. To make it short, I used paraffin heat candles instead of the isobutane burner it was designed for. The butane burner never leaves soot, and when you pack the Eta up, everything packs pack into the boiling vessel.

The heating canles worked (a tribute to how well the Eta works), and I was able to keep my body heat up. However it left significant soot marks on the heatsink structure. This is a problem since the Eta's boiling vessel IS the outer packaging too. This means that the heatsink leaves black stars on all my clothinkg.

I have no idea what surface treatment it has, but I don't want to damage it. I've been driving myself crazy trying to get it clean with water, detergent and pipe cleaners. Is there a chemical way that will soften up the soot enough so I can scrub it off without damaging my favourite (and in this case life saving) Eta Solo?

Sincerely yours

NileRed you could have used a Soxhlet extractor to extract the theobromine more efficiently - this is what my group did for our final year HND project. I can send you the full details of the method we carried out if you want. Essentially, we added 10 g of finely grated chocolate (almost like a powder) into a paper thimble for the Soxhlet extractor. We then added 100 ml of 0.1 M HCl to the round bottom flask and refluxed the sample for approx. 1 hour. Then we took a small aliquot of the final liquid, separated the fat and particulate matter by centrifuge and analysed the results by HPLC. You could, however just transfer the liquid extract into a clean beaker and simmer on a hot plate until the volume has reduced significantly then filter the theobromine crystals as you did before.

First: really fun video! :)

Second: you should consider getting a Soxhlet extractor; the solvent efficiency of your extraction step would probably have been improved considerably by using one. You probably also lost quite a bit of your yield percentage to your final filtration step since the total yield is already quite small; in your place, I probably would have redissolved the theobromine in an appropriate solvent directly from the filtration funnel and recrystallized it.

Edit: looks like some folks beat me to the punch with the Soxhlet extractor comment. You shouldn't need to mix the cocoa with anything to get the extractor to drain, though; any sufficiently fine filter paper ought to do the trick as long as you don't let it block the draining tube.
